awd_titl_txt: Networks for CS Teacher Development: Building Robust Location Based Models of Teacher Learning and Community
awd_abstract_narration:
The State University of New York (SUNY) at Albany and the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) propose a project to build the capacity of local CSTA chapters to create robust communities of teachers with increased sense of professional identity as computer science (CS) teachers. Currently, CSTA coordinates a network of over 70 local chapters in 39 states and Puerto Rico, with requests to start new chapters arriving every quarter.  The expectation is that these chapters are teacher-led communities supporting their members' professional development. In practice though, local chapter leadership often struggles to create a vision for their work, leaving many chapters without defined goals or a sense of ownership of their work, and many CS teachers without a pathway to evidence-based ongoing professional learning. The goal of this project is to provide local chapters with the support they need to create robust communities that meet the professional needs of their members. 

The project will create a "Chapter in a Box" toolkit for defining chapter visions and goals, host an annual summit to develop volunteer chapter leadership, nurture a professional learning community among local chapter leadership, and provide support to local chapters in developing evidence-based professional development that meets the needs of local teachers. It will investigate two research questions. The first question focuses at the chapter level:  How do the CSTA activities support the chapters in building capacity and ownership for their local chapter development? The second, two-part question, focuses at the teacher level: What kind of professional identity do CSTA teacher members bring to their CS teaching practice? and How does the local CSTA chapter influence teachers' perceptions of their professional identity and their use of evidence-based CS programs in the classroom? Outcomes of this project will be measured through the growth of CSTA chapter capacity and CSTA members' CS teacher professional identity, the implementation of evidence based professional development programs in the chapter regions, and connections between teachers of computer science and local CSforAll movements. The improvements resulting from this project have the potential to reach tens of thousands of CS teachers nationwide and to build our knowledge on how best to support teachers as they switch into CS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The project implemented four key activities to build the capacity of Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) chapters in establishing strong communities of computer science (CS) teachers: 1) developing a "Chapter in a Box" toolkit guiding local chapters in developing shared visions and goals and providing evaluative tools to measure progress, 2) conducting an (bi) annual Chapter Leadership Summit to empower local volunteer leadership in utilizing the toolkit, 3) building a professional learning community among local chapter leadership, and 4) providing mini-grants for chapters to implement professional learning programs aligned to local visions and goals.

Through this grant, CSTA has been able to work directly with more than 600 Chapter Leaders to scale professional learning initiatives across our extensive network of more than ninety active CSTA chapters reaching nearly 12,000 chapter members. The project has significantly expanded the network of chapter leaders, supporting the hosting of 656 events in the 2022-23 program year. These events have impacted ~4,400 unique members and ~18,000 attendees overall, who teach an estimated 123,000 students. In comparison, when the project began in 2019, CSTA had 78 chapters in total, hosting 275 events and reaching far fewer educators. 

The incorporation of regional chapter support coordinators, a change stemming from this grant's research, has strengthened CSTA chapters in fostering local communities and providing continuous professional development for CS teachers in their regions. A total of $38,209.08 in chapter mini-grants was awarded to seven cohort chapters to support the implementation of professional development programs and attendance at events aimed at advancing computer science education in their respective states.

Just before the CSTA annual conference in July 2022, we hosted our first in-person Chapter Leadership Summit since 2019. We provided scholarships for two Chapter Leaders per chapter to attend both the Chapter Leadership Summit and conference, totaling approximately 220 Chapter Leaders representing 85 chapters. The event featured 24 breakout sessions aligned with the Chapter Success Rubric, in addition to plenary & chapter planning sessions, from six tracks suggested for various leadership roles. Participants received 9.5 hours of structured professional development, with  95% of them rating the overall quality of the summit as above average or excellent. In comparison, the 2019 summit, at the project's inception, had 72 confirmed participants representing 60 chapters. 

Additionally, the project designed and administered a member satisfaction survey that could be used by all chapters.  Each chapter received a customized report comparing their satisfaction levels with those of all other chapters. The survey garnered responses from 1,850, 2,561, and 3,399 chapter members in 2021, 2022, and 2023 respectively. The results revealed that the greatest value members received was “connecting with other CSTA members” followed by “access to standards and resources.” Most (strongly) agreed that they had someone or some way to ask questions and receive support. Most were satisfied with their chapter activities and felt their perspective was welcomed and honored. 

Through the lens of teacher professional identity, the project examined the impact of CSTA chapters on the continuous growth and development of computer science teachers. Insights from chapter leader focus groups and member surveys revealed that CSTA chapters served as vital resources of social-emotional support, amplifiers of teachers' voices, and nurturers of their professional identities. Noteworthy challenges faced by chapter leaders included teacher recruitment, leadership transitions, and the establishment of a cohesive group identity.

The project also developed and validated the Computer Science Teacher Identity Survey, a quantitative tool designed to assess computer science teachers' professional identity. Two versions of the survey were field tested through the computer science teacher landscape surveys in 2020 and 2022. The validated instrument comprises six indicators of CS teacher identity: CS teaching commitment, CS pedagogical confidence, confidence to engage students, sense of community and belonging, perceived value of CS education, and perceived local support. The survey provides a valuable resource for researchers and educators seeking to further understand and support the development of teacher professional identity and capacity for computer science education. 

Using the Computer Science Teacher Identity Survey, the project empirically identified five profiles of U.S. teachers of computer science: (1) committed, confident, and well-resourced proponents (24%); (2) committed, confident but under-resourced proponents (18%), who valued computer science education, were committed, confident, but had low sense of community and inadequate local support; (3) moderates (30%) with average identity scores; (4) unconfident and under-resourced proponents (16%), who had low confidence, commitment, and local support, but still valued computer science education; and (5) uncommitted, unconfident, and under-resourced skeptics (11%), who scored low on all six indicators. Each profile exhibited distinct characteristics tied to professional backgrounds and teaching contexts. Findings also underscored the strong association between computer science teachers' professional identity and factors such as teachers' CSTA membership, primary teaching responsibility, teaching experience, and exposure to post-secondary computer science coursework.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Lijun Ni
